TEXT.TITLE: South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands

ORIGINAL-REFEX.REFEX: South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands

PARAGRAPH.STRING: (SGSSI) is an overseas territory of the United Kingdom in the southern Atlantic Ocean.
was governed as part of the Falkland Islands Dependencies.

is a remote and inhospitable collection of islands, consisting of South Georgia - which measures approximately 100 miles by 18 miles and is by far the largest island in the territory - and a group of smaller islands known as the South Sandwich Islands. There is no native population on any of

, and the only inhabitants are the British Government Officer, scientists and support staff from the British Antarctic Survey who maintain scientific bases at Bird Island and the capital, King Edward Point, and museum staff at nearby Grytviken.

The British sovereignty of South Georgia dates from 1775, and that of the South Sandwich Islands from 1908. British arrangements for the government of South Georgia were first established under the 1843 British Letters Patent, with permanent local British administration and resident Magistrate since 1909 exercising effective possession, enforcement of British law, and regulation of all economic, scientific and other activities in the territory.

Argentina claimed South Georgia in 1927 and the South Sandwich Islands in 1938. From 1905 the Argentine Meteorological Office cooperated in maintaining the meteorological observatory at Grytviken under the British lease requirements of the whaling station until these changed in 1949.
